 Abstract This analysis considers changing patterns of population mobility in terms of shifts in productive structure and social relations of production. It is based on the premise that migration analysis cannot be divorced from an historical perspective, and in particular that in many low-income regions recent changes in population mobility have to be understood in terms of the colonial legacy and the attempted transition to capitalist industrialization. In that context, it concludes with a critical review of government policies designed or expected to influence migration rates and patterns, arguing that often the policies have effects quite contrary to those intended by their advocates.

IratroductLon Population mobility has become one of the most pressing and con- fusing demographic and social issues of the latter part of the twentieth century, both a symptom of profound changes in productive structures, and in national and international divisions of labour, and a contributing factor to such changes. Governments of all political hues in most parts of the world have long come to regard population distribution as a greater cause of long-term concern than population growth per se, as revealed in the much-cited United Nations' surveys of government perceptions. This is illustrated by the 1980 survey, which showed that in every part of the world more governments regarded the spatial distribution of their population as a cause of concern than their fertility levels (table 1). Social scientists who have attempted to assess the phenomenon have been split. Some have regarded migration as growing at a rapid rate in recent years, contributing to "excessive urbanisation" and the growth of huge "mega-cities", to chronic urban-open unemployment, worsening income inequality, ecological stress, population maldistribution and a growing threat to the social fabric. Others have been far less alarmed, depicting mobility as a necessary part of economic growth, evidence of equilibrating tendencies, a factor facilitating industrialisation, improving income distribution, inducing technical change in agriculture, reducing population growth and easing social tensions, mainly but not only in those areas from which the migrants move. Overlaying those two admittedly extreme views are two "policy" perspectives. There are those who readily admit that the evidence is far from conclusive that migration causes various adverse trends but that governments would be advised to check migration for some social, economic or political benefit. Conversely, there are those who admit there may be (short-term) adverse effects but that freedom of movement is a basic human right, 1 Thus even according to the 1978 survey, the overwhelming majority of "developing" country governments saw population distribution as a greater source of development problems than population growth. The "liberal" position is that a person who moves chooses to do so and is doing so to improve his welfare, so that interference with that choice reduces that welfare. These contrasting views have been expressed in their extreme form to illustrate the range of opinion and the significance of the issues. But analysis and policy prescription have scarcely been helped by several basic failings. First of all, the extent of population mobility has been grossly underestimated, for two main reasons. The concepts used to indicate population mobility have been inadequate in most censuses and surveys, and in studies based on them, while the type and extent of data collected on mobility have been relatively scanty and neglected compared with that relating to other demographic phenomena. Conceptually, there has been a persistant tendency to limit the per- ception of population mobility to "long-term changes in residence", and even there dilemmas have remained over whether that should be restricted to changes in place of usual (de jure) residence or whether it should be extended to changes in de facto residence, the latter being likely to give much higher measures of population movement. Typically, attention has been concentrated on rural-urban migration and/or moves that involve crossing a regional or state boundary. Such practices not only result in underestimates of mobility but are liable to give distorted images of the underlying patterns. Thus, to give a simple example, in India 1971 census data based on inter-state long-term migration suggested that male mobility greatly exceeded female; but in fact women predomi- nated in intra-state migration, often moving for marriage but also for other reasons. That leads to a fundamental concern, which is that, with the current state of knowledge, recommended "migration policies" are likely to be ill-conceived, poorly implemented or inadequately monitored. Briefly, there are three main reasons for that. First, with the shortcomings of most available data, policies geared to one sort of mobility may be implemented when another form of migration is actually far more widespread. Second, the methodologies for analysing the efficacy of policies - even for fully identifying the objectives and the direct and incdirect effects to be considered - are scarcely developed.  - 6 - :II. Pre-colonial and Pre-capitalist Mobility Patterns The human species is not a migratory one. But in rudimentary societies mobility has bee:ni a way of survival - the first mode of existence, as Marx called it. TID be able to trace the inter-relationships between social relations, population growth and territorial mobility, it is essential to identify "early" forms of mobility, in part because many r emain highly relevant in the world and in part because socio-economic change can be expected to have different effects on different forms of population mobility. Schematically, territorial mobility in pre-capitalist eras can be split into ecological migration, immobilisation and social migration. The first has been lound throughout history and persists today in certain undeveloped parts of the world. Essentially, it reflects an imbalance between natural resources and population, given available technology. Survival in such circumstances has been best pursued through mobility, as a way of life and of subsistence. One should further distinguish between collective and individualistic forms of ecological trigration, as surnmarised in figure 1. There are four main forms of collective mobility. The first is Inomadic movement - a terrn derived from the Greek "to pasture' - and consists of herders who move over an extensive territory seasonally and cyclically, as dictated by climate and local resources. These tend to be omitted from discussions of migration, but are possibly the closest to the lay impression of the meaning of migration. They remain a major phenomenort in some parts of the world, although sedentisation has reduced their prominence in recent years. The second and third forms of ecological migration are hunting-and- gathering and cultivating, both of which have been less predictable in character than nomadic mobility, and less inclined to be circulating. Hunters and gatherers roam in search of food, hunting and picking the vegetation in any area through which they pass until it is nearly exhausted, when they resume their travelling. Cultivating migration embraces those communities who have traditionally been forced to pursue non-sedentary or shifting cultivalion, notably through forms of "slash- and-burn" cultivation.

They contrast sharply with patterns of temporary migration in class-structured societies, whether "feudal" or uLndergoing partial or total transformation to capitalist production, and most strikingly perhaps in the colonies of Central and South America, Africa and Asia. Unlike ecological migration, immobilisation is based crucially on the existence of social classes and exploitative relations of procluction.1 Of course, there have been many reasons for immobility, including ignorance, :fear of the unknown and physical incapacity. Yet there have been pervasive forms of social control restricting mobility or directing it which have been far more prevalent in some types of society than in others. Resort to surch controls has in part been a function of population density and growth, but has fundamentally reflected the social relations of production and distribution. Scarcely less restrictive has been serfdom. In feudal Europe serfs were "tied to the soil" by legal and extra-legal regulations. And in the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries landlords and other ruling groups in colonial territories in Latin America, the Caribbean, Africa and much of Asia responded to the typically low population density by tying peasants to small plots of land by rental obligations, often forcing them to serve regular and protracted periods of labour service. Again, these situ- ations have persisted in some places late into the twentieth century; but in many places where they were used to control mobility they have been replaced, for reasons discussed later. Involving less coercion but nevertheless considerable localised pressures and sanctions have been social controls, whereby tribes, kinship groups and villages of cultivators have evolved webs of recipro- cal obligations based on kinship or lineage relations dictating the communal division of labour and the extent and form of movement. It is the breakdown of such reciprocities in communities under stress that has contributed to the growth of some forms of territorial mobility. A related form of restriction on mobility in "pre-capitalist" com- munities is the practice of patronage, used to considerable effect by colornal landowners, but long predating colonialism. Often this has taken the form of paternalism, whereby peasants would place themselves under the protection of a powerful landlord and in return provide rent, in the form of labour, a share of the produce or cash rent. Ccmmonly, the patron-client relation extended to fictive kinship, as in many parts of Latin America, whereby the landlord adopted a peasant's child or acted as a godfather. Apart from the immobility and ecological migration in pre-capitalist societies there has also been social migration, which has been more individualistic than collect.ive in nature. It is of course true that there have been many mass movements associated with local wars or flight from a conquering force. But perhaps of much greater signifi- cance have been individualistic movements in what could be described as stress migration. In this, the role of population growth has been twofold. Growth of peasant farnilies has led to land fragmentation, with descendents sharing land, often subdivided into small parcels scattered across a village; this in itself has reduced living standards and land productivity, and made work on the land more onerous and time-consurning. In many rural areas, the contrived absence of a land market has limited the ability of peasant communities to overcome this tendency through land sales and consolidation. In Malaysian kampongs, to take an example that has persisted into the 1980s, the result has been temporary and longer-term out-migration coupled with chronic underutilisation of land, with the lack of drainage on one plot under- mining the productivity of adjoining plots. Another major impact of population growth has been through its influence on the forms and levels of exploitation in agrarian communities. Where landlords (or other groups controlling the means of production or in a position to extract surplus from the peasants) have stipulated rents and imposed local "taxes", the growth in size of peasant households has reduced their ability to pay. But the demographic expansion of landlords' households has also had an impact, through increasing their need for revenue to maintain their accustomed standard of living. There have, of course, been other factors raising that need for revenue and reducing the peasants' ability to pay accustomed rents. But a common result has been rising rents with constant or declining peasant incomes, forcing some to migrate temporarily in search of additional income or a cash income. Historians can point to many instances in which lancdlords subjected peasants to such high rents that many of them fled, as was often t'he case in parts of Thailand and Viet Nam,

In many places, a related tendency has been for local or national ruling elites to impose local taxes that have grown excessive for similar reasons, leading to mass flight. Often, stress migration has been a mass movement, but it has been individualistic in character. A quite different form of individualistic migration long predating the penetration of capitalist relations of production is trade migration. Merchants have commonly come from ethnic or religious minorities and have been instrumental in setting up new ports or market towns, gather- ing round them a retinue of servants, workers and others supplying them with goods, so that merchants have been pioneer migrants drawing residents from other areas because of the incomes they were generating.3 Somewhat related has been transilient migration, that is a life of regular movement in response to localised economic fluctuations, consisting primarily of itinerant traders and migratory labourers who have been a large category of populations throughout history. In many parts of the world, youths -mostly men - would be expected to leave their villages for a period to gain experience, skills and petty spoils. As a rite de passage, this has been a necessary part of gaining adulthood and a means of ensuring a man social status in the village on his return. doc.repnme: Population mobility and productive relations : demographic links and policy evolution
doc.abstracts: This analysis considers changing patterns of population mobility in terms of shifts in productive structure and social relations of production. It is based on the premise that migration analysis cannot be divorced from an historical perspective, and in particular, that in many low-income regions recent changes in population mobility have to be understood in terms of the colonial legacy and the attempted transition to capitalist industrialization. In that context, it concludes with a critical review of government policies designed or expected to influence migration rates and patterns, arguing that often the policies have effects quite contrary to those intended by their advocates. There is a danger that desperate movement by the world's poor will be a main cause of economic stagnation, unemployment and poverty; however, severe measures taken to control this movement, which deny the human right to freedom of movement, should not be allowed to supersede measures tackling the underlying structural causes of the perceived maldistribution of the population.
